all_procs.procedure_1.csv:
item,trial type,max time,text,shuffle 1,weight,freeview_image, 0,instruct,user,"Thank you for participating - you are about to start an eye-tracking task.

In this task we will ask you to look at some dots to train the camera to know where your eyes are looking.

After this we will present you with pairs of images. You can look wherever you like on the screen. ",off,1,, 2,webgazer,user,"Please look at the cross.
A pair of images will follow. You are free
to look at either image.

Do not move your head,
only use your eyes.",off,1,gaze_pairs1.csv, 0,instruct,user,Please take a break before starting the second half of the eyetracking task.,off,1,, 3,webgazer,user,"Please look at the cross.
A pair of images will follow. You are free
to look at either image.

Do not move your head,
only use your eyes.",off,1,gaze_pairs2.csv,

borcsok_ethics.csv:
School of Psychology

Earley Gate,
Whiteknights
PO Box 238,
Reading
RG6 6AL,
UK
phone +44 (0)118 378 8523
fax +44 (0)118 378 6715

Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study

Information & Consent Sheet

Researchers:

Supervisors: Email: Phone:
Dr Anthony Haffey Anthony.Haffey@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850
Dr Lily Fitzgibbon l.t.fitzgibbon@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850


Experimenters Email
Rebecca Borcsok r.borcsok@student.reading.ac.uk

You are being invited to take part in some research. Before you decide whether or not to participate, it is important for you to understand why the research is being conducted and what it will involve. Please read the following information carefully.

What is the purpose of the research?

We are conducting research exploring eye movements when viewing neutral or pleasant images. The purpose of the study is to determine if individual differences influence attentional behaviour. Your participation in this study will require one 30-minute session.

Who is carrying out the research?

The data are being collected by Rebecca Borcsok, under the supervision of Dr Anthony Haffey and Dr Lily Fitzgibbon, in the School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences at University of Reading. The research has been approved by the School and University ethics committees.

What happens if I agree to take part?

If you agree to take part in this research, you will be asked to take part in a task where you will view matched pairs of images, whilst your eye movements are recorded. You will also be asked to complete a video-game style task, which records your decision-making. After the two tasks, you will also be asked to complete some questionnaires, including some that ask about your alcohol and gambling behaviours. At the end of the study, you will be debriefed on the tasks you have completed and given further information on the aims of the study.

Are there any risks associated with taking part?

One risk of taking part in this study is the issue of confidentiality. To ensure that information about your personal use of alcohol or gambling behaviour is known by to as few members of the research team as possible, this information will be held by Rebecca Borcsok only, until the study is complete. You will be identified by code only during the study, so you cannot be matched with information about alcohol use or gambling. After the study is complete, all identifying information will be removed, and only subject codes (and non-identifying information) would be matched to information about your alcohol use and gambling behaviour.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Information linking that number to your name will be stored securely and separately from the data you provide us. All identifiable information collected for the project, such as the consent form, will be destroyed after a period of 60 months from the when the completion of the project has elapsed.

An analysis of the information will form part of our report at the end of the study and may be presented to interested parties and published in scientific journals and related media. Note that all information presented in any reports or publications will be anonymous and unidentifiable.

Is participation voluntary and what if I wish to later withdraw?

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

What if I have other questions?

If you have further questions about this study, please do not hesitate to contact the student experimenter or supervisors listed above.
I confirm that I have read the information sheet for this study. I have had the opportunity to consider the information, ask questions and have had these answered satisfactorily.
I understand that all personal information will remain confidential to the Investigator and arrangements for the storage and eventual disposal of any identifiable material have been made clear to me.
I understand that participation in this study is voluntary and that I can withdraw at any time without having to give an explanation.
I am happy to proceed with my participation.

trialtypes.instruct: {{text}}
trialtypes.webgazer:
This experiment is based on code from the OSF repository https://osf.io/jmz79/ which accompanies the publication "Online webcam-based eye tracking in cognitive science: a first look" by Semmelmann & Weigelt, published in Behavior Research Methods in 2017. Please find the abstract and information about the code, analyses, and data below. This work is intended for scientific use only. Written by Kilian Semmelmann, tolcam@ksemmelm.de, 2017.

Updates by Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk) 2020 to make this a task that works on Collector.

Webcam Setup


You can take a short break and move your head. Before continuing, please follow the instructions noted below.

Please turn off your mobile phone and close all other programs and websites. Then carefully read and follow these instructions:

If possible, please adjust your position until your face matches the picture below as much as possible:


This study consists of multiple five-minute parts with pauses inbetween. After you clicked "start", please avoid moving your head. If you move too much, the calibration can fail and you might not be able to finish the study.

Proceed


Click "Proceed" to move onto the next trial
<
>
0
+
X
no message
trialtypes.setup:
<script>
/*
* From the PEBL battery 
*/
parent.parent.card_lists = [{
    gain: {
      A: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - frequent high losses
      B: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - infrequent very high losses
      C: 50,    // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - frequent low losses
      D: 50     // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - infrequent moderate/high losses
    },
    
    /*
    * Decks A and C
    */
    // red card signifies a loss
    // black card signifies a gain
    
    /*
    * Decks B and D
    */
    // sometimes get a red card with no associated loss (red has no meaning)
    
    
    loss: {
      A: [0,0,150,0,300,0,200,0,250,350,
          0,350,0,250,200,0,300,150,0,0,
          0,300,0,350,0,200,250,150,0,0,
          350,200,250,0,0,0,150,300,0,0],
      B: [-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,1250,0, 
          -1,-1,0,1250,0,-1,-1,0,0,0,
          1250,0,-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,
          -1,1250,0,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0],
      C: [0,0,50,0,50,0,50,0,50,50, 
          0,25,75,0,0,0,25,75,0,50, 
          0,0,0,50,25,50,0,0,75,50,
          0,0,0,25,25,0,75,0,50,75],
      D: [-1,0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,0,0,250,
          -1,-1,0,0,-1,0,0,0,-1,250,
          0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,-1,0,250,0,
          0,-1,0,-1,250,-1,0,0,-1,0] 
    }
  }]
  
parent.parent.earnings = 2000
parent.parent.borrowed = 0

Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},0);
</script>

modified_childhood_experiences.csv:
Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you.
Prior to your 18th birthday:

1. Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often
Swear at you, insult you, put you down, or humiliate you? Or
Act in a way that made you afraid that you might be physically hurt?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True

2. Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often
Push, grab, slap or throw something at you? Or
Ever hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True

3. Did you often or very often feel that
No one in your family loved you or thought you were important or special? Or Your family didn't look out for each other, feel close to each other, or support each other?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True

4. Did you often or very often feel that
You didn't have enough to eat, had to wear dirty clothes, and had no one to protect you? Or
Your parents were too drunk or high to take care of you or take you to the doctor if you needed it?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
5. Was a family member ever lost to you through divorce, abandonment, or other reason?
VALUE OF 4 AS IT IS EXTREME!

6. Was your mother or stepmother:
Often or very often pushed, grabbed, slapped, or had something thrown at her? Or
Sometimes, often, or very often kicked, bitten, hit with a fist or something hard? Or
Ever repeatedly hit over at least a few minutes or threatened with a gun or knife?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
7. How frequently did anyone in your household drink too much alcohol?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
8. How frequently did anyone in your household do street-drugs?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
9. How frequently was a household member struggling with mental health problems such as depression?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
10. How frequently did household members have legal problems?
Never True|Rarely True|Sometimes True|Often True|Very Often True
social_media_disorder.csv: During the past year, have you
regularly neglected other activities (e.g. hobbies, sport) because you wanted to use social media?
often found it difficult not to look at messages on social media when you were doing something else (e.g. school work)?
often used social media so you didn't have to think about unpleasant things?
often felt tense or restless if you weren't able to look at your messages on social media?
tried to spend less time on social media, but failed?
felt the need to check messages on social media more and more often?
tried to reduce your use of social media, but failed?
often sat waiting until something happens on social media again?
regularly lied to your parents or friends about the amount of time you spend on social media?
regularly felt angry or frustrated if you weren't able to use social media?
been unable to stop using social media, even though others told you that you really should?
regularly had no interest in hobbies or other activities because you would rather use social media?
often felt bad when you could not use social media?
often used social media to escape from negative feelings?
had serious conflict with your parent(s) and sibling(s) because of your social media use?
had serious problems at school or at work because you were spending too much time on social media?
regularly found that you can't think of anything else but the moment that you will be able to use social media again?
regularly had arguments with others because of your social media use?
jeopardised or lost an important friendship or relationship because you were spending too much time on social media?
regularly felt dissatisfied because you wanted to spend more time on social media?
regularly used social media to take your mind off your problems?
regularly not had enough sleep because you were using social media too late at night?
regularly devoted no attention to people around you (e.g. family or friends) because you were using social media?
felt the need to use social media more and more often?
regularly hidden your social media use from others?
often not paid attention at school, while doing homework or at work because you were using social media?

How long after you wake up do you check social media? Please enter an answer in MINUTES.
If you do NOT own any social media accounts, please enter 10000
audit.csv:
INSTRUCTIONS
For question 1-8, please answer based on how much you drank in the last 12 months
For q9 and 10 please answer generally
1. How often did you have a drink containing alcohol?
Never|Monthly or less|Two to four times a month|Two to three times a week|Four or more times a week
2. How many drinks containing alcohol did you have on a typical day when you are drinking?
1 or 2|3 or 4|5 or 6|7 to 9|10 or more
3. How often did you have six or more drinks on one occasion?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
4. How often did you find that you were not able to stop drinking once you had started?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
5. How often did you fail to do what was normally expected from you because of drinking?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
6. How often did you need a first drink in the morning to get yourself going after a heavy drinking session?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
7. How often did you had a feeling of guilt or remorse after drinking?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
8. How often were you unable to remember what happened the night before because you had been drinking?
Never|Less than monthly|Monthly|Weekly|Daily or almost daily
9. Have you or someone else been injured as a result of your drinking?
No|Yes, but not in the last year|Yes, during the last year
10. Has a relative, or friend, or a doctor or other health worker been concerned about your drinking or suggested you cut down?
No|Yes, but not in the last year|Yes, during the last year
pathological_narcissism.csv: For the following items, please reply from 0 (not at all like me)to 5 (very much like me)
1. I can usually talk my way out of anything.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
2. When people dont notice me, I start to feel bad about myself.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
3. I often hide my needs for fear that others will see me as needy and desperate.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
4. I can make anyone believe anything I want them to.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
5. I get annoyed by people who are not interested in what I say or do.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
6. I find it easy to manipulate people.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
7. Sometimes I avoid people because Im concerned that theyll disappoint me.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
8. I typically get very angry when Im unable to get what I want from others.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
9. When others dont meet my expectations, I often feel ashamed about what I wanted.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
10. I feel important when others rely on me.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
11. I can read people like a book.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
12. Sacrificing for others makes me the better person.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
13. I often fantasize about accomplishing things that are probably beyond my means.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
14. Sometimes I avoid people because Im afraid they wont do what I want them to do.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
15. Its hard to show others the weaknesses I feel inside.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
16. Its hard to feel good about myself unless I know other people admire me.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
17. I often fantasize about being rewarded for my efforts.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
18. I am preoccupied with thoughts and concerns that most people are not interested in me.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
19. I like to have friends who rely on me because it makes me feel important.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
20. Sometimes I avoid people because Im concerned they wont acknowledge what I do for them.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
21. Its hard for me to feel good about myself unless I know other people like me.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
22. It irritates me when people dont notice how good a person I am.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
23. I will never be satisfied until I get all that I deserve.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
24. I try to show what a good person I am through my sacrifices.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
25. I often fantasize about performing heroic deeds.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
26. I often fantasize about being recognized for my accomplishments.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
27. I cant stand relying on other people because it makes me feel weak.
Not at all like me|Very much like me
28. When others get a glimpse of my needs, I feel anxious and ashamed.
Not at all like me|Very much like me

consent_jf1.csv:
School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences
Whiteknights
Reading RG6 6AL

University of Reading


Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study


Consent Form


Investigator(s): Email: Telephone:
Anthony Haffey anthony.haffey@reading.ac.uk -01183788523-
Chen Zhao c.zhao5@reading.ac.uk
Nicholas Hedger n.hedger@reading.ac.uk
Researcher(s):
Joe Forrest j.forrest@reading.ac.uk
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.
I am happy to be contacted about future studies (optional)
info_jf1.csv:
School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences
Whiteknights
Reading RG6 6AL

University of Reading


Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study


PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET


Investigator(s): Email: Telephone:
Anthony Haffey anthony.haffey@reading.ac.uk -01183788523-
Chen Zhao c.zhao5@reading.ac.uk
Nicholas Hedger n.hedger@reading.ac.uk
Researcher(s):
Joe Forrest j.forrest@reading.ac.uk
We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study.

What is the study investigating?
We are conducting research exploring eye movements when viewing neutral or pleasant images. The purpose of the study is to determine if individual differences influence attentional behaviour. Your participation in this study will require one 30-minute session.

How will my data be stored?
Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

Are there any risks associated with taking part?
Some of the questionnaires may include material of a sensitive nature. Thus, the study may include a mild risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions.

Do I have to take part?
Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason.

Will I be compensated?

You will receive 0.5 credits through SONA.



This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct

([SREC OR UREC NUMBER])

.

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Joe Forrest or Anthony Haffey using the details above.

Thank you for your help.

autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.

University of Reading


School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences

Reading RG6 6AL

Researcher 1 Researcher1@reading.ac.uk
Researcher 2 Researcher2@reading.ac.uk

Title of Study: [Study title]

Consent Form
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.
I am happy to be contacted about future studies (optional)

empathy_quotient_40.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I can easily tell if someone else wants to enter a conversation.
I find it difficult to explain to others things that I understand easily, when they dont understand it the first time.
I really enjoy caring for other people.
I find it hard to know what to do in a social situation.
People often tell me that I went too far in driving my point home in a discussion.
It doesnt bother me too much if I am late meeting a friend.
Friendships and relationships are just too difficult, so I tend not to bother with them.
I often find it difficult to judge if something is rude or polite.
In a conversation, I tend to focus on my own thoughts rather than on what my listener might be thinking.
When I was a child, I enjoyed cutting up worms to see what would happen.
I can pick up quickly if someone says one thing but means another.
It is hard for me to see why some things upset people so much.
I find it easy to put myself in somebody elses shoes.
I am good at predicting how someone will feel.
I am quick to spot when someone in a group is feeling awkward or uncomfortable.
If I say something that someone else is offended by, I think that thats their problem, not mine.
If anyone asked me if I liked their haircut, I would reply truthfully, even if I didnt like it.
I cant always see why someone should have felt offended by a remark.
Seeing people cry doesnt really upset me.
I am very blunt, which some people take to be rudeness, even though this is unintentional.
I do not tend to find social situations confusing.
Other people tell me I am good at understanding how they are feeling and what they are thinking.
When I talk to people, I tend to talk about their experiences rather than my own.
It upsets me to see an animal in pain.
I am able to make decisions without being influenced by peoples feelings.
I can easily tell if someone else is interested or bored with what I am saying.
I get upset if I see people suffering on news programs.
Friends usually talk to me about their problems as they say that I am very understanding.
I can sense if I am intruding, even if the other person doesnt tell me.
People sometimes tell me that I have gone too far with teasing.
Other people often say that I am insensitive, though I dont always see why.
If I see a stranger in a group, I think that it is up to them to make an effort to join in.
I usually stay emotionally detached when watching a film.
I can tune into how someone else feels rapidly and intuitively.
I can easily work out what another person might want to talk about.
I can tell if someone is masking their true emotion.
I dont consciously work out the rules of social situations.
I am good at predicting what someone will do.
I tend to get emotionally involved with a friends problems.
I can usually appreciate the other persons viewpoint, even if I dont agree with it.
info_sheet.csv:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Title of Project: [[Your project title]].

Name of Lead Investigator: [[Investigator]] ([[Institute]])

Invitation paragraph

You have been invited to take part in a research study. Before you decide whether to take part it is important for you to understand why the research is being done and what it will involve. Please take time to read the following information carefully and discuss it with friends and relatives if you wish to. Ask us if there is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information. Take time to decide whether you wish to take part or not. Thank you for reading this.

What is the study about?

[[describe your experiment here]].

What does the study involve?

[[what the participant will do]]

Why have I been chosen?

[[criterion, e.g. age, etc.]]

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form. If you decide to take part you are still free to withdraw at any time during the data collection without giving a reason.

I am interested in taking part, what do I do next?

Please find a quiet room with minimal distractions. Please ensure you have a good internet connection on a PC / laptop / tablet device. [[optional: Please do not run the study on a mobile phone]]. Make sure that you have about [[time needed]] minutes time to complete the study. Once ready please follow the link to the online study.

What if I agree to take part and then change my mind?

That is fine. If you decide to withdraw you would need to provide your participation ID to the researchers. The researcher will then delete all the data generated by that ID from their computers.

What are the possible disadvantages and risks of taking part?

[[describe risks etc. here]]

What are the possible benefits of taking part?

[[benefits here]]

Who can I complain to?

If you have a complaint regarding anything to do with this study, you can initially approach the lead investigator [[lead investigator]] ([[lead_investigator_email]]). If this achieves no satisfactory outcome, you should then contact [[person to contact next]]

Will my taking part in this study be kept confidential?

All information which is collected about you during the course of the research will be kept on a password protected database and is strictly confidential. You will be given an ID code which will be used instead of your name. Your data will be shared with the following collaborators:
[[list of collaborators]]

[[optional: Your anonymised data can be shared with other research teams interested in understating it further.]]
The raw data will be stored for up to 10 years after a study has been completed.
Members of the faculty human research ethics committee may require access to check that the study has been conducted in accordance with the approval.

What will happen to the results of the research study?

The results based on performance of the group of participants will be then analysed and submitted for publication in peer reviewed scientific journals.

Who is organising and funding the research?



[[information about researchers and funders here]]

Who has reviewed the study?

This study has been reviewed and approved by [[your ethics committee]].


How is data secured?

Data is encrypted in Collector on the participant's computer. This data cannot be decrypted without the researcher's password. For more information, go to: https://some-open-solutions.github.io/collector/encryption.html

Contact for Further Information

[[your contact information]]
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue
info_sheet_uor.csv:
School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences
Whiteknights
Reading RG6 6AL

University of Reading


Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET


Investigator(s): Email: Telephone:
Anthony Haffey anthony.haffey@reading.ac.uk -01183788523-
Chen Zhao c.zhao5@reading.ac.uk
Nicholas Hedger n.hedger@reading.ac.uk
Researcher(s):
Joe Forrest j.forrest@reading.ac.uk
We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study.

What is the study investigating?
We are conducting research exploring eye movements when viewing neutral or pleasant images. The purpose of the study is to determine if individual differences influence attentional behaviour. Your participation in this study will require one 30-minute session.
How will my data be stored?
Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

Are there any risks associated with taking part?
Some of the questionnaires may include material of a sensitive nature. Thus, the study may include a mild risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions.

Do I have to take part?
Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason.

Will I be compensated?
You will receive 0.5 credits through SONA.You will receive 2.50 through Prolific.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Joe Forrest or Anthony Haffey.

Email: Investigator1, Tel: +44-(0)118-378-8850.

Thank you for your help.

default_trialtypes.webgazer:
This experiment is based on code from the OSF repository https://osf.io/jmz79/ which accompanies the publication "Online webcam-based eye tracking in cognitive science: a first look" by Semmelmann & Weigelt, published in Behavior Research Methods in 2017. Please find the abstract and information about the code, analyses, and data below. This work is intended for scientific use only. Written by Kilian Semmelmann, tolcam@ksemmelm.de, 2017.

Updates by Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk) 2020 to make this a task that works on Collector.

Webcam Setup


You can take a short break and move your head. Before continuing, please follow the instructions noted below.

Please turn off your mobile phone and close all other programs and websites. Then carefully read and follow these instructions:

If possible, please adjust your position until your face matches the picture below as much as possible:


This study consists of multiple five-minute parts with pauses inbetween. After you clicked "start", please avoid moving your head. If you move too much, the calibration can fail and you might not be able to finish the study.

Proceed


Click "Proceed" to move onto the next trial
<
>
0
+
X
no message

user_trialtypes.setup:
<script>
/*
* From the PEBL battery 
*/
parent.parent.card_lists = [{
    gain: {
      A: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - frequent high losses
      B: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - infrequent very high losses
      C: 50,    // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - frequent low losses
      D: 50     // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - infrequent moderate/high losses
    },
    
    /*
    * Decks A and C
    */
    // red card signifies a loss
    // black card signifies a gain
    
    /*
    * Decks B and D
    */
    // sometimes get a red card with no associated loss (red has no meaning)
    
    
    loss: {
      A: [0,0,150,0,300,0,200,0,250,350,
          0,350,0,250,200,0,300,150,0,0,
          0,300,0,350,0,200,250,150,0,0,
          350,200,250,0,0,0,150,300,0,0],
      B: [-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,1250,0, 
          -1,-1,0,1250,0,-1,-1,0,0,0,
          1250,0,-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,
          -1,1250,0,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0],
      C: [0,0,50,0,50,0,50,0,50,50, 
          0,25,75,0,0,0,25,75,0,50, 
          0,0,0,50,25,50,0,0,75,50,
          0,0,0,25,25,0,75,0,50,75],
      D: [-1,0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,0,0,250,
          -1,-1,0,0,-1,0,0,0,-1,250,
          0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,-1,0,250,0,
          0,-1,0,-1,250,-1,0,0,-1,0] 
    }
  }]
  
parent.parent.earnings = 2000
parent.parent.borrowed = 0

Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},0);
</script>
